weblit-Navigation.intro: How do you get around the web? Browsers are the software we use to explore the web. They can quickly direct us exactly where we want to go, or can take us on a winding path to serendipitously discover new interests. Sharpening your navigation skills can help you browse faster, make use of speedy new short-cuts and add-ons, and get more from the time you spend on the web each day.

discover.title: What’s a web browser?
links: It’s one of the most important pieces of software on your computer. But many people don’t even know what it is! This page quickly explains what browsers are and why they matter.

discover.title: Tips and tricks
links: Level up your browser skills with these tips and tricks for Firefox. Keyboard and mouse shortcuts, automating common searches, organizing tabs and more. (Here’s similar tips for Chrome, Internet Explorer, Safari and Fedora.)

discover.title: Watch the evolution of the web
links: The web is like a living, breathing ecosystem. This beautiful interactive timeline shows how much it has grown and changed since its birth in the early 1990s.

discover.title: Navigating “filter bubbles”
links: Are you stuck in a filter bubble? How do you know what you’re seeing on the web is the same as what others are seeing? Watch Eli Pariser’s TED Talk, The Filter Bubble, to learn more about online filtering.

make.title: Supercharge your browser
make.description: Add-ons for your browser can help you navigate more easily—plus simplify tasks and unlock new powers. Trick out your Firefox browser with add-ons.

make.title: Navigate like a superhero
make.description: Test yourself on web navigation basics. Working with URLs in your navigation bar, copying and pasting text, finding image URLs and more.

kits.title: Ways of the Web
kits.description: Lead learners through the Ways of the Web with this hands-on teaching kit
kits.author: Mozteach

ctas.title: Become a mentor
ctas.description: Teach others web navigation, coding and other digital skills.

ctas.title: Make your own teaching kit
ctas.description: Use our templates to make your own teaching kits and activities like these.

ctas.title: Get together
ctas.description: Find or host a webmaker event with others around the world.

weblit-WebMechanics.intro: What happens when you browse the web? Clicking on a link or entering a URL in your browser initiates a series of behind the scenes operations that define your experiences on the web. Recognizing the relationships between the moving parts of the web, like IP addresses and URLs, makes the overall browsing experience more rewarding, and helps you make smart choices about the content you consume and share online.

discover.title: Not a Series of Tubes
links: Despite popular belief, the Internet is not a series of tubes. This video from “Don’t Fear the Internet” explains how the internet and web sites actually work.

discover.title: What’s it built with?
links: What makes your favorite web sites tick? Paste in their address here to see what technologies they’re built with.

discover.title: What can you learn from a URL?
links: Where in the world is the computer that hosts your website located? Enter any address in the URL Demystifier to find out.

discover.title: What’s my IP address?
links: Your “Internet Protocol” address is what lets your computer talk to other computers on the Internet. This tool will show you what IP address you’re using right now.

discover.title: Who owns the Internet?
links: Learn more about the ownership structures of the world’s largest public resource.

make.title: Mash up the web with Popcorn Maker
make.description: See how embedding resources from sites like Wikipedia, You Tube or Flickr rely on web mechanics.

make.title: Explain the evolution of the web in your own way
make.description: Write a blog post, make a web page, or create a Popcorn video about the web’s history, evolution or future.

make.title: Hack Google
make.description: Wouldn’t it be cool if you could “hack” websites like Google or Facebook? Now you can—safely. And you’ll learn a bit about web mechanics while doing it.

kits.title: Speed dating for web mechanics
kits.description: Make learning about the elements of the web fun for students.
kits.author: Julia Vallera, Hive NYC

kits.title: The Markup Mixer
kits.description: A Post-It note activity that helps learners build a basic understanding of markup.
kits.author: @malesser + @thomashpark

ctas.title: Become a mentor
ctas.description: Teach others web mechanics, coding and other digital skills.

ctas.title: Make your own teaching kit
ctas.description: Use our templates to make your own teaching kits and activities like these.

weblit-Search.intro: Can the web be harnessed? With millions of new web pages being added to the Internet every month, the web can feel chaotic—even overwhelming. Using effective search techniques can make the difference between a frustrating web experience and an empowered one.

discover.title: How good a searcher are you?
links: Put your skills to the test with these search challenges. See how quickly you can track down answers on everything from Che Guevera to ancient Egypt, in categories like culture, geography, history and science.

discover.title: What is connected to the internet?
links: Find devices connected to the web with Shodan From routers and cell phones to coffee makers and luxury cars.

discover.title: The worlds first computational knowledge engine
links: <script id="WolframAlphaScript" src="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/embed/?type=largeannot" type="text/javascript"></script>

discover.title: Search Creative Commons images
links: Find free openly-licensed images from multiple sources using this handy Creative Commons search hub.

discover.title: Go back in time
links: Search the Internet’s past with the Internet Archive’s Way Back Machine. See what your favorite sites looked like back in the day.

discover.title: What is the world searching for?
links: See what the rest of the world is searching on Google right now. Visualize hot searches or explore trends. What’s more popular—cats or dogs?

discover.title: Don’t want your searches to be tracked?
links: Search without letting your searches be tracked using Do Not Track.

discover.title: There are many ways of indexing information and then searching through those indexes.
links: Here are a couple more interesting search engines to try. Spezify - Visual Search, Lightswitch, <>

discover.title: How does search work?
links: What happens when you Google something? This video shows the life span of a search query.

make.title: Make an interactive concept map
make.description: Use instaGrok to research and share an interactive concept map of your search on a particular topic.

make.title: Tell a story with GIFs
make.description: Search and find the perfect series of animated GIFs to tell a story.

make.title: Change your browser’s default search bar
make.description: Step-by-step instructions on how to change the search bar in various web browsers.

kits.title: Image seeking for fantastic visual metaphors
kits.description: Lead learners through the process of finding reusable images to represent concepts and ideas.
kits.author: Alan @Cogdog Levine

kits.title: Help learners become better searchers
kits.description: Lesson plans, power search tips and ways to help students search academic sources.
kits.author: Google Education

kits.title: Hold a SEO battle with kids
kits.description: Help learners improve their websites’ search rankings
kits.author: Meredith Summs

weblit-Credibility.intro: Can we believe everything we see on the web? The Internet contains a confounding mix of facts, opinions, advertising, hidden agendas and pranks. Sharpening your “crap detector” helps you identify credible content on the web, and reminds you to approach certain web sites with a healthy dose of skepticism.

discover.title: Strengthen your Crap Detector
discover.description: How do you separate the good stuff from the bad? Howard Rheingold explains how to separate accurate information from inaccurate information, misinformation and disinformation.
links: Read about Crap Detection 101
Check out this Crap Detection mini-course
Does it pass the “CRAP Test?” A quick and easy evaluation process: consider a web page’s Currency, Reliability, Authority and Point of View.

discover.title: Hone your Internet Detective skills
links: Doing online research? Here’s some clues and evidence to look for when deciding whether a site is legitimate.

discover.title: Fact-check like a pro
links: Use this journalist’s toolbox to detect urban legends, hoaxes and scams with this comprehensive toolbox for myth-busting, fact-checking and more.

make.title: Punk a friend
make.description: Use the X-Ray Goggles to remix a friend’s social media profile, their favorite web site, or a news article to give them a funny surprise. Explore how easy it can be to make something fake look legit.

make.title: Remix a news web page
make.description: Use the NewsJack tool to remix the news. Try changing the ads, altering headlines, or explore the visual and linguistic cues that signal credibility.

make.title: Spot hidden persuasion techniques in You Tube videos
make.description: Identify hidden persuasion and propaganda techniques in ads, films and conspiracy videos. Then write, make a web page or video about what you discovered.

kits.title: Create your own evil twin
kits.description: Teach learners how to use HTML and CSS by creating a customized profile page for their Evil Twin
kits.author: mozteach

kits.title: Choosing good websites for your research
kits.description: Lesson materials for helping students discuss and assess good rating criteria
kits.author: Common Sense Media

kits.title: Teaching critical thinking
kits.description: Activities and lesson plans on source-checking, online sharing, detecting hidden propaganda, and more.
kits.author: Digital Disruption

weblit-Security.intro: How do you protect yourself online? The web works by connecting every computer and device in the world. This offers astounding opportunities, but also exposes us to risk. With the right skills, tools and software, you can protect yourself and remain secure.

discover.title: Increase your security with add-ons
links: Install these 10 Firefox add-ons to secure your web browser.

discover.title: What is Heartbleed?
links: Learn about one of the web’s most serious vulnerabilities, and how to combat it.

discover.title: Block ads
links: Learn more about Adblock Plus, an add-on that prevents sites from employing cookies that track your activity online and blocks irritating website ads.

discover.title: Preventing identity theft
links: Identity theft is serious business. Here’s a primer from the University of Texas to understand the key signs.

discover.title: The security mirage
links: The feeling of security and the reality of security don’t always match, says computer-security expert Bruce Schneier. In this talk he explains why we spend billions to address certain kinds of risks while avoiding others.

make.title: Create a how-to video for the Lightbeam project
make.description: Learn about the Mozilla Lightbeam project, which tracks those who are watching you online, and then add your own flavor to the issue by remixing this Popcorn video and enhancing it with your own sound and images.

make.title: Remix a graphic novel about mobile security
make.description: Modify this Thimble page created by a Webmaker community member to add your own take on mobile security in graphic novel format.

make.title: Create a strong Internet password
make.description: This article and the companion video by the Mozilla Support team will show you how to create secure, easy-to-remember passwords.

kits.title: How to teach privacy and security concepts
kits.description: This teaching kit outlines a set of hands-on activities for helping participants learn basic privacy practices quickly
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman, Emma Irwin + others

kits.title: Remix for cybersafety
kits.description: Explore security through remixing with the X-Ray Goggles
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman and Emma Irwin

weblit-Composing.intro: What makes creating for the web different? Hyperlinks, multimedia, up-to-date content—these features make the web powerfully interconnected and different from media of the past. When you write and build specifically for the web, recognizing your audience as an interactive part of the process will allow you to tell stories and build experiences in ways that television, books and other media can’t.

discover.title: A brief history of storytelling
links: Explore the connections between early cave paintings, video games and today’s web.

discover.title: What do screens want?
links: An essay by designer Frank Chimero examines what makes creating for the web unique.

discover.title: Explore some introductory HTML
links: This Code Academy tutorial is great for learning the basics of HTML, the language of the web.

discover.title: Get familiar with HTML and CSS
links: HTML and CSS coding cheat sheets that help you with the basics.

discover.title: The Machine is Us/ing Us
links: Watch a viral video about what makes hypermedia different.

weblit-Remix.intro: Many of our greatest creative accomplishments are made as a reaction to someone else. Nowhere is this more evident than on the web. Remixing the ideas of others by adding your own spin can let you turn something old into something new, talk back to media, or stand on the shoulders of giants to make your own statement on the web.

discover.title: Listen to a remix
discover.description: These mashups are songs made from bits of other songs.
links: The Grey Album, DJ Dangermouse’s remix of JayZ and The Beatles
Girl Talk creating a mashup on his couch by remixing Elvis Costello
Pop Danthology 2013: a mashup of 68 different songs

discover.title: Watch DJ Kutiman’s “Thru You” remix
links: A mashup created by remixing hundreds of uploaded You Tube clips

discover.title: Learn about sampling and hip-hop
links: “Raiding The 20th Century” by DJ Food is an in-depth exploration into remix

discover.title: Watch a documentary about remix culture

weblit-DesignAccessibility.intro: Should using the web be enjoyable for everyone? As more people across the globe come online with phones and tablets, ensuring that the web is viewable across multiple devices has become an increasingly urgent challenge. Understanding CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) and the principles of good design help make interacting with web pages a pleasure.

discover.title: Know your font
links: Try this quiz by Ironic Sans to test your knowledge.

discover.title: Design for Programmers
links: A series of 50 interactive challenges to learn how to implement design online

discover.title: CSS with HTML5DOG
links: Get started learning CSS.

discover.title: Designer’s News
links: Browse through a Hacker’s News-style feed tailored to designers.

discover.title: Your website on different devices
links: See what your site looks like in different formats with this Am I Responsive tool.

discover.title: Web accessibility primer
links: Understand how people with disabilities experience the web.

discover.title: What Screens Want
links: Find out what it means to design with screens in mind in this article by Frank Chimero.

discover.title: Resize that!

weblit-CodingScripting.intro: How does the web respond to you? Interactivity has become essential to our web experience. How does that work? Small programs known as scripts run in the background of our web browsers, automating hundreds of tasks and allowing our web experiences to be seamlessly responsive. Understanding the role of scripting languages like JavaScript helps us maximize the interactive potential of the web, making our overall online experiences more awesome.

discover.title: Learn JavaScript
links: Explore the Mozilla Developer Network’s JavaScript resource for beginner to advanced programmers.

discover.title: Why Programming Matters
links: Watch this Hour of Code video where programmers explain how scripting changed their life.

discover.title: Computer programming with Khan Academy
links: Check out this Khan Academy course in computer science.

discover.title: JavaScript for Cats
links: A fun introduction for new programmers.

discover.title: Learn Javascript while gaming
links: Play Code Combat, a fun game that teaches programming.

weblit-Infrastructure.intro: What’s the difference between apps, the web and the Internet? There’s a bewildering array of words used to describe the global network we use to communicate and share data. Understanding the basic underlying technology that makes up the Internet, and how it differs from the web and services like email, helps us grasp what happens to the data we share and guides us towards making smarter choices online.

discover.title: What’s the difference between the Web and the Internet?
links: This Wikipedia article explains all.

discover.title: What is the Internet, really?
links: Andrew Blum’s TED talk about the underwater cables, secret switches and other physical bits that make up the net.

discover.title: The Internet Stack
links: Understand how the foundational technologies of the web work.

discover.title: Printing out the Internet, page by page
links: A crowdsourced art project to print out the entire Internet, in honor of deceased open free-information activist Aaron Schwartz.
More about this project in the Washington Post.

discover.title: The Story of Send
links: Take a journey through Google’s data centers by following an email along its path.

discover.title: How the Internet works in 5 minutes
links: The Internet is not a fuzzy cloud. This video by Aaron Titus explains.

weblit-Sharing.intro: Great ideas should be shared. For a concept to grow from a seedling into a tree, it needs to spread beyond one or two people. Using appropriate tools for sharing means that whole communities can share individual discoveries.

discover.title: Ten leading platforms for creating online communities
links: Browse this ZDNet list of tools that help communities organize people on the web and accomplish work in a highly collaborative manner.

discover.title: Radical tools to empower communities in the museum sector
links: As museums go digital, more activities are created and produced through community collaborations. This blog post discusses the approaches of the Santa Cruz Museum of Art and History.

discover.title: How can I share large files online for free?
links: Lifehacker review of some of the best services to share easily and quickly with friends and colleagues.
And a similar list by PC Advisor

discover.title: Asynchronous and synchronous classroom discussion methods
links: Thoughtful examination of e-learning management systems for different kinds of learner needs by the Chronicle of Higher Education.

discover.title: A short written history of collaborative methods
links: Wiki page by the University of British Columbia that outlines the tools, sources and theories of group communication from the 1940s to the present day.

weblit-Collaborating.intro: There’s only so much one person can do alone.  Fortunately, the web allows us to connect with others across distances, languages and cultures. Honing our online collaboration skills lets us do more than just send better emails—it helps us build things on the web faster, better and smarter.

discover.title: Ways to make your experience of online forums more productive
links: The 7 habits of effective online discussion participants.

discover.title: Github, Academia and Collaborative Writing
links: Git’s decentralized nature makes it an excellent tool for coordinating collaborative editing.

discover.title: How the Web Changed Everything
links: Watch this talk by Cory Doctorow, one of BoingBoing’s founding editors, on how the web lets us use collaboration to be “super human”.

discover.title: Effective Crowdsourcing
links: Check out these Mashable articles on different kinds of crowdsourcing.

links: Watch this TED talk by Wikipedia’s founder Jimmy Wales.

weblit-Community.intro: Who owns the web?  One of the beautiful things about the web is that it is a global, public resource. Learning to collaborate online as part of a global community of contributors and creators is an empowering way to ensure that the web remains a shared resource for everyone.

discover.title: Mozilla Community guidelines
links: Participation Guidelines for involvement in the Mozilla Community.

discover.title: GitHub Community guidelines
links: Github provides code management for groups and communities. Here are its various participation guidelines.

discover.title: The Hive Learning Network
links: Hive creates opportunities that enable learning through hands-on making and exploration with peers and mentors. Learn about the path towards creating and sustaining this kind of network.

discover.title: Digital Is
links: An open community of educators sharing, publishing and remixing each others work.

discover.title: Source
links: Source is an OpenNews project designed to amplify the impact of journalism code and the community of developers, designers, journalists, and editors.

links: Code as a research object.

make.description: Whether you write code, want to translate Webmaker into a new language, host an event or teach someone, there are many ways to get involved in this open source project.

weblit-Privacy.intro: Your personal information is valuable. That’s why it’s vital that you are the one in charge of controlling how your personal information gets shared. That way, you can take steps to prevent others from tracking you, using your data in ways you don’t like, or spying on you without your knowledge or consent. This page includes steps anyone can take to make their online lives more private and secure. It also explores some of the larger ideas and debates around privacy, trust and your digital footprint.

discover.title: See who’s tracking you online
links: Watch the video. As you surf the Web, information is being collected about you. This “Tracking the Trackers” TED Talk video explains how.
Try it for yourself. Install the Lightbeam add-on to see for yourself. Shine a light on who’s watching your online activities.

discover.title: Tell sites you don’t want to be tracked
links:
Enable “Do Not Track.” You can tell sites to stop tracking your browsing history using this simple change to your browser settings. Here’s how:

  • Firefox
  • Internet Explorer
  • Safari
  • Chrome
  • Opera

discover.title: How to turn on private browsing
links: If you don’t want anyone with physical access to your computer to see what you’re doing online, you can enable “private browsing.” This deletes cookies, temporary Internet files and browsing history after you close the window.

discover.title: See how much your personal data is worth to marketers
links: How much buyers would pay for your information? Use this interactive calculator from the Financial Times to find out.

discover.title: Adjust your social network settings
links: Facebook—Click the settings cog in the upper right corner of your screen, then click Privacy Settings >> “Who can see my stuff.”
Twitter—Click the settings cog, then “Settings.” You can adjust settings like adding or removing your location to tweets, or make your tweets private so that only people you approve can see them.
Google+—go to Home >> Settings to adjust who can interact with you, comment on your posts, or start a conversation.

discover.title: Learn more about surveillance and spying
links: NSA Files Decoded: What the revelations mean for you. The Guardian newspaper’s interactive exploration on what the National Security Agency is collecting about you.
Learn more about your own meta-data. What social networks, devices and services do you use? What meta-data does that reveal about you to the NSA and others?

discover.title: Learn more about the “Stop Watching Us” campaign
links: StopWatching.us is a coalition of more than 100 public advocacy organizations, companies and prominent figures speaking out against mass surveillance.

discover.title: Thinking about your digital footprint and reputation
links: Check out Abbas’s story from Common Sense Media about making conscious choices around what you share and how you represent yourself online.

Making choices about what to post or share—sharing things online is what makes the web great. But sharing embarrassing or personal things about yourself or your friends can come back to haunt you. This short video walks you through it.
Over-sharing, identity and respect. WNYC’s Radio Rookies interview youth and others about over-sharing, online identity, responsibility, sexism and more.

make.title: Make a music video about privacy, surveillance or online freedom
make.description:
Use Popcorn Maker to make a video. You could use videos you find on the web, music, pictures, animated GIFs or your own voice commentary.

  • “Party at the NSA.“ Check out this example from @keyboardkat. Then remix it to make it your own.
  • Or make your own from scratch. This guide walks you through how to use Popcorn Maker for the first time.

make.title: Write about who’s tracking your online
make.description: Use Lightbeam to gather research about who’s tracking you online. Or do research about government surveillance. Then tell a story about what you’ve learned. You could publish it as a web page with Thimble, make a multimedia essay with Popcorn, or just write a blog post or tweet about it.

make.title: Host a “crypto-party” for you and your friends
make.description:
There are various things you can do to make your online data more secure. Some are harder than others. If you want to take extra steps to protect your communications, here are some ways to go further.

  • Install HTTPS Everywhere. A collaboration between The Tor Project and Electronic Frontier Foundation, this extension encrypts your communications to make your browsing more secure.
  • Learn more about the Tor Project. If you’re more ambitious, you can use tools like Tor to defend yourself against network surveillance and traffic analysis. Here’s how to get started. Or check out The Guardian’s explanation on how Tor works.
  • Volunteer with Tor. Tor is a free network that relies on bandwidth donated by volunteers around the world. Want to help? This guide and video show you how.
  • Host a crypto-party. Now that you’ve learned how to encrypt your data, why not help others? This “CryptoParty” guide can help. You can also add your event to Mozilla’s Maker Party to join others hosting web literacy parties around the world.

kits.title: Privacy and security teaching kit
kits.description: This teaching kit provides a complete mini-course or curriculum with activities for teaching privacy and security basics.
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman, Emma Irwin, Ben Moskowitz, Atul Varma, Alina Hua, Stacy Martin, Matthew Willse, and Shane Caraveo

kits.title: Screen this 17-minute documentary about privacy and youth
kits.description: It includes a teacher’s guide for screening the 17-minute “Our Privacy Matters” mini-documentary.
kits.author: Leslie Shade, Karen Smith, Giuliana Cucinelli, & Patrick MacInnis

kits.title: Get people talking and debating about privacy, tracking and surveillance.
kits.description: This “spectrogram” ice-breaker activity is designed to get people up, moving and talking about the issues.
kits.author: Laura Hilliger, Dumitru Gherman and Emma Irwin

kits.title: Play “Privacy and Security Bingo”
kits.description: This activity can be used as an ice-breaker or in offline settings. Share privacy concepts with a group of learners, and learn more about how others relate to their own privacy.
kits.author: Karen Smith

kits.title: “Social Media the Wrong Way.”
kits.description: Guide learners through the process of making a terrible social media profile page, as a way to learn privacy best pratices and a bit of HTML at the same time.
kits.author: MozTeach

kits.title: How to teach online privacy when you don’t have internet access.
kits.description: How to teach online privacy when you don’t have internet access. Or in low bandwidth situations.
kits.author: Kat Braybrooke, Karen Smith, Julia Vallera, Jess Klein and Chad Sansing.

more.title: Teaching privacy and network education in schools.
more.description: Cory Doctorow’s take on how teachers and parents can teach privacy and network education the right way. And why many schools may be inadvertently sending the wrong message.

more.title: Get free training from Mozilla.
more.description: On how to teach online privacy, security, digital citizenship and more.

weblit-OpenPractices.intro: How do we spread ideas? To help the network grow and to let new ideas flourish, the web is based on open standards that can be studied, reused and improved by anyone. Licenses define what’s possible with the code and content we find online, and understanding how they work allows you to participate in the web’s evolution.

discover.title: What is openly licensed content?
links: This wiki page by Creative Commons explains the basics.

discover.title: What are OERs?
discover.description: This page by UNESCO explains what OERs (Open Educational Resources) are, and how they might manifest in our societies.
links: What are Open Educational Resources (OERs)?
And here’s another useful description by the London School of Economics
Want to know even more? Here is a comprehensive guide by JISC

discover.title: The evolution of open knowledge—a crowdsourced community timeline
links: A history of openness from 1425 to the present day, based on events contributed by communities. And here’s the project this timeline was built for, The Open Book.

discover.title: Yochai Benkler TED talk: Open-source economics
links: In this 17 minute speech, law professor Yochai Benkler explains how open and collaborative projects like Wikipedia and Linux represent the next stage of human organization.

discover.title: The 9 most important events in open source history
links: What are the key moments in time that made open source software such an immense success story?

discover.title: An overview of some of the most popular Open Source Licenses
links: Written by the Open Source Initiative

discover.title: P2PU’s School of Open
links: Learn about P2PU’s School of Open

discover.title: What’s happening in open source today?
links: This online publication focuses on how open source is applied to different areas including business, education, government, health, law and other disciplines.

make.title: Contribute to an open source project on Github
make.description: This useful guide will help you get started quickly.

make.title: License your web content using Creative Commons
make.description: This page leads you through the process of choosing the right license for your work.

make.title: Create your own open source project
make.description: Creating an open-source project isn’t just about making your code freely available to others. This step-by-step guide in Smashing Magazine explains how to make it happen.

make.title: Report on an event and release its content for free
make.description: Remix this Thimble page to share the details of an event or meetup and share its content with a creative commons license of your choice.

kits.title: Join a Webmaker Training session
kits.description: Wondering how to apply open practices to Webmaker? Get involved in the next Webmaker Training and learn how to teach vital web literacy skills in your own community:
kits.author: Community

kits.title: And here’s a quick “Get Started” page
kits.description: that you can remix for your own needs
kits.author: @laura

kits.title: What’s the right license for the job?
kits.description: Choosing the right CC license for a work can be a deliberative and thought-provoking process, but it doesn’t have to be. This activity by P2PU helps learners understand how to pick the right license for the job.
kits.author: P2PU

kits.title: Design Challenge: Cultural Licenses
kits.description: Facilitate this activity by Mozilla’s Kat Braybrooke and the Tate Britain’s Luca Damiani to lead a group through the process of determining an open cultural license and then discussing how it works with different kinds of content
kits.author: Kat Braybrooke, Mozilla

kits.title: Understanding Hacking with Hive India
kits.description: This kit by Webmaker community member Tanay Pant shares a variety of articles that help mentors spread awareness about the “open” sides of hacker culture
